p: There are only a few references made to using mint herbs for cardiovascular and urinary systems. Pliny wrote of pennyroyal as a diuretic and as one capable of removing bladder stones [ 17], an idea also defended by Aulus Cornelius Celsus (Celsus, c. 25 BCâ€“c. 50) in regard to spearmint [ 112]. Later, Trota also advised using horsemint and pennyroyal in baths or fumigations to help with strangury (i.e., slow and painful discharge of small volumes of urine), likely due to their diuretic effect [ 38]. Interestingly, recent studies have shown that menthol does indeed have beneficial effects on the urinary system.
